Award.AbstractNarration: The Conflict Consortium will bring together two groups of scholars for the purposes of solidifying relationships in the field of subnational conflict, developing a list of best practices as well as most commonly utilized variables to assist in field development and to provide instructions for others in the fields of political science and sociology who wish to understand, use and create their own databases. These workshops will improve the current research in this area, lead to greater accumulation of findings in the future and provide guidance to those in as well as those consider work in this area of research. The Consortium will also attempt to provide the framework within which data projects could be better coordinated with one another and courses taught on the subject at diverse venues around the globe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There have been numerous outcomes from the award.  We held two successful conferences where we convened meetings of first established and then younger scholars - each meeting had approximately 20 researchers.  This led to numerous collaborations, which was somethat that we wanted to achieve. Also out of these meetings we generated a "best practices" document concerning how best to create a database on political conflict, violence and peace.  

Related to this, we created a project webpage (conflictconsortium.weebly.com) in order house relevant documents like the best practices report, facilitate event management (i.e., our efforts to convene conflict consortium dinners and residential meetings at conference and providing advice on diverse topics). We use the site to collect information on diverse scholars for networking purposes and to offer a variety of other services that are still rolling out.  

In addition to this, we created a virtual workshop in order to provide junior scholars with feedback on their work and we have filmed these sessions in order to allow the broader audience to learn from them.  Thus far we have completed 41 episodes, which are provided from the youtube channel created for the project.  The workshop has been especially successful in that it has not only garnered 3,188 views thus far but it has spawned three copies/spinoffs as well (the Peace Science Society's Online Symposia, the rightstrack and one from economics that I cannot remember the name of).

Spinoffs from this effort continue. For example, we recently developed a listing of political science departments that address the topics conflict, violence and peace programs throughout the United States to assist individuals in selecting programs (thus far with 3200 reads).  Next year, we will rank institutions, provide more detail about what is being done within the different institutions as well as extend the review to include public policy schools and institutes on University campuses.
